data.title: Actresses Charlotte Rampling and Kristin Scott Thomas, Illustrated by
data.meta_description: Spotlight on Charlotte Rampling and Kristin Scott Thomas, in fine dramatic form. By Laura Jacobs. Portraits by David Downton.
data.text:
Charlotte Rampling and Kristin Scott Thomas—a generation apart and quite different actresses. Rampling arrived in the mid-60s with a smoky gaze and the slinky physique of an Egon Schiele, her beauty so silent, catlike, and clawed that her surname has practically become a verb—to rample. (“For a female to render a male helpless with a kind of coldly elusive sexuality” is how Urban Dictionary defines it.) Last winter, at age 68 no less, Rampling was named the new face of Nars cosmetics. Scott Thomas appeared in the mid-80s, more classically romantic, more gleamingly British (all those crisp t’s in her name), with a Maid Marian clarity in the eyes and brow.

What the two do have in common—along with great bones—is a voice. Neither Rampling nor Scott Thomas was ever the violin. It is the cello’s timbre, deep-toned and complex, that has shaped their work and the characters they play. Rampling, so often cast in mysteries with an existential edge, has just joined the cast of the dark English TV crime drama Broadchurch, now entering its second season. And September brings Scott Thomas’s next film, My Old Lady. Shot in a Paris of stones and shadows, co-starring Maggie Smith and Kevin Kline, it brings a lilt to the Freudian notion of the family romance. Interestingly, Scott Thomas and Rampling have both spent much of their lives in France, not only making movies there but marrying Frenchmen. The English novelist and Francophile Nancy Mitford, describing the challenges Englishwomen face competing with the clever females of France, once wrote, “These poor English roses just hang their lovely heads and droop and die.”

Not these roses.

Culture

Paris Olympics 2024 Opening Ceremony Serves Lady Gaga, Celine Dion, and a Drag Last Supper

At the rain-drenched opening ceremonies for the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics, Celine Dion performed for the first time in four years, as did Marie Antoinette's severed head.

Style

Lady Gaga, Ariana Grande, Tom Cruise, and More A-Listers Pack the Stands at Paris Olympics for Return of Simone Biles

Stars poured into Bercy Arena on Saturday to watch the renowned American gymnast compete for the gold.

Fashion

Through Bill Cunningham’s Lens, the Glitz and Drama of an Era-Defining Fashion Show

An exclusive early look at the photographer’s treasure trove, published together for the first time in The Battle of Versailles: The Fashion Showdown of 1973.

Hollywood

Robert Downey Jr. Returns to The Avengers, But Not as Iron Man

The Iron Man star will play iconic villain Doctor Doom in Marvel's next two Avengers movies.

Award Season

Joan Chen Has Always Been a Movie Star. Hollywood Is Finally Catching Up

The veteran actor has worked with Bernardo Bertolucci, David Lynch, and Ang Lee, and maintained rich careers in both China and the US. With the new film Dìdi, Oscar buzz is trailing her for the first time. What took so long?

Television

These 2024 Summer Olympic Athletes Have Main-Character Energy

From a cheese-wheel-toting Italian gymnast to an Egyptian fencer who competed while seven months pregnant, here’s a guide to the athletes who went viral at the Paris Games.

Royals

Duchess Sophie Moved to Tears at the 2024 Paris Olympics

Prince William and Kate Middleton are unlikely to make an appearance at this year’s Olympics despite its close proximity to the UK, but Princess Anne and Duchess Sophie have already witnessed a few history-making moments.

Television

The 25 Best Shows on HBO and Max to Watch Right Now

Stop aimlessly scrolling: We’ve got all the recommendations you need.

Television

The 2024 Summer Olympics Are Best as a Streaming Event

Watching the Paris games via the Peacock app has greatly expanded our Olympics diet.

Politics

Could Global Tensions Puncture the Olympic Bubble?

The Olympics are often viewed as a respite from politics, but multiple wars and rising global tensions will be hard to ignore this year. “I’m here to bring awareness,” says Valerie Tarazi, a swimmer representing Palestine at the 2024 Summer Games.
